Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>Colin, about your suggestion #2: Joseph Reisinger has done some 
>interesting work on varying the fitness function in order to get a 
>more robust genetic encoding.  The idea is that if the fitness 
>function varies but there is some underlying theme that is conserved 
>(such as symmetry) the organisms will need to evolve to be able to 
>represent that underlying theme efficiently even though they can't 
>rely on any particular instance of it.  This does imply that 
>calamities can lead to robustness, but it appears than an important 
>ingredient in such a system is an encoding that can encapsulate 
>information about underlying themes, i.e. an indirect encoding.  
>Here's the paper:
>
>http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?reisinger:gecco05
>
>  
>
Cheers, I'll add it to the reading list :) I guess there are different 
levels at which this changing of the fitness function can have an 
effect, or at least there are different ways of thinking about what is 
going on. E.g. A fitness function may differ in that the local maxima 
are in different places, so switching acts as a gentle way of keeping 
the population moving and not getting stuck (maybe). What you seem to be 
talking about is the evolution of individuals that have an increased 
ability to adapt.

Colin.
